title: Wednesday, 23rd August, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Ok!

PM11:01am

Fair bit going on

PM11:01am

But August rule still applies: if we run out of things to say we've run out of things to say

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Let's get a pic up

PM11:02am

BE11:02am

Oh, hello.

11:02 am
PM11:02am

That's Baroness Mone

PM11:02am

Pic of today

PM11:02am

But I can't tell you why she's pic of the day

11:02 am
BE11:02am

Baroness Mone of Mayfair, to give her her full title.

PM11:03am

But when you see other media using her as pic of the day, you'll immediately understand why

PM11:03am

Sorry, thanks for the correction Bryce

11:03 am
undefined
PM11:03am

You got those Paratek snaps Bryce?

BE11:03am

Oh, hold on .....

11:03 am
BE11:04am

*PARATEK IS SAID TO WEIGH SALE AMID TAKEOVER INTEREST

BE11:04am

That's Bloomberg at 10am.

PM11:04am

It's almost four months since we put our proverbials on the line on this one

11:04 am
BE11:04am

*PARATEK IS SAID TO WORK WITH ADVISERS TO REVIEW OPTIONS

PM11:04am

SOmetimes wonder why we do it.

BE11:04am

*PARATEK PHARMACEUTICALS HASN'T MADE A FINAL DECISION

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Schlep to Mayfair and back, x times.

PM11:04am

Print the stuff

PM11:04am

Nothing happens

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Everyone sneers at us

PM11:05am

We lose confidence

PM11:05am

In ourselves and in our sources

11:05 am
PM11:05am

See whether Bloomberg have more luck smoking this out

BE11:05am

Hm. People following the story will have noted that Paratek did a change of control policy change back on August 7, which flagged up pretty clearly that something was going on.

PM11:05am

Our backstory stuff here: https://ftalphavil...arma-firm-in-play/

11:05 am
PM11:06am

Good point on change of control

PM11:06am

See what the Paratek price does later

PM11:06am

Think it's been drifting back of late

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Despite that Aug 7 move

PM11:07am

Arash -- not confirmed yet, of course

undefined
11:07 am
PM11:07am

Anyway, shall we be our own worst enemy?

BE11:07am

Sure! Thumbs up

PM11:07am

Ok

11:07 am
PM11:08am

RAW

PM11:08am

Read the disclaimer

PM11:08am

And don't trade before you've read what we write

11:08 am
PM11:08am

And don't trade before you think

PM11:08am

Rhythm One

PM11:09am

Think it might be in merger talks with YuMe

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Actually, more than "think"

PM11:09am

This is from usually very informed sources

PM11:09am

Dunno about price tho

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Or the terms

PM11:10am

But something is going on

BE11:10am

............ Okay, that would certainly make a lot of sense.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

I think these two tried to tie the knot a couple of years ago

BE11:10am

They did. http://news.sky.co...us-merger-10335503

PM11:10am

Similar size, arent they

11:10 am
BE11:10am

They are. And identical markets, pretty much.

BE11:11am

And YuMe has had Deutsche in for a strategic review since the back end of 2016.

BE11:11am

Here's what Paul Porrini, YuMe's CEO and President, said about the strategic review on the last conference call.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Analyst
With regards to strategic alternatives with Deutsche Bank, is that just potentially YuMe being acquired? Or are you looking at other companies also?

Paul Porrini:
So it's a broad-based strategic alternatives exercise, we're looking at any ways that we can add value and return value to shareholders. So there are really no real limitations on it, whether it's buy-side, sell-side, M&A or whether it's other things, like optimizing around capital allocation, for example, with respect to the dividends and the stock buybacks. So you'll recall, we've reloaded the shareholder value with about $45 million in the last 18 months via the dividends and the stock buyback. So it's -- I think, I'd characterize as a broad-based exploration of value-enhancing activities.

BE11:13am

I'd say "a broad-based strategic alternatives exercise" would certainly take in reviving a cost-cutting merger that collapsed a couple of years back.

PM11:13am

Indeed

11:13 am
PM11:14am

Who is the big hedgie behind Rhythm One?

BE11:14am

(@wayneJ: that Compaq and HP merger quote comes to mind, but I won't repeat it here out of politeness.)

PM11:14am

Ive clean forgotten

11:14 am
PM11:14am

Anyway

RhythmOne PLC (RTHM:LSE): Last: 37.00, no change, High: 37.50, Low: 36.50, Volume: 443.50k
PM11:15am

That's stale of course

11:15 am
PM11:15am

39.75 live

PM11:15am

And when there's no statement. You can decide we're pants and curse us for four months or so

undefined
11:16 am
PM11:17am

So which Footsie stock got spanked today then!

BE11:17am

WPP today, since you ask.

WPP PLC (WPP:LSE): Last: 1,402, down 192.01 (-12.05%), High: 1,478, Low: 1,382, Volume: 10.23m
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Results suck!

BE11:17am

Guidance sucks even more!

PM11:17am

But people thought they were going to be bad

11:17 am
BE11:18am

We expected WPP to guide down -- see the stuff written on the back of the Dentsu warning a week or so ago, for instance -- but that's only part of the problem here.

BE11:18am

What's happened is that organic growth turned negative for the first time since 2009.

BE11:18am

As a result, FY guidance is lowered to +0-1% versus +2% previously.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Blame on the usual stuff. Weaker FMCG and packaged goods spending along with account losses.

BE11:19am

Oddly enough, the only market to remain positive organic growth-ly on a stronger trend was ... the UK!

BE11:20am

Where there's -- how do I put this? -- a couple of wee uncertainties looming.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

So 2Q revenue £3.262bn -3% below consensus

BE11:20am

Organic growth of -1.7% vs consensus +0.5%

BE11:20am

Which, bearing in mind April was up 0.5%, means May-June were down a pretty catastrophic -2.4%.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

And July's worse! Down -2.6%

BE11:21am

All of which means the 0-1% guidance for the full year looks really quite optimistic.

BE11:21am

Sorrell's optimism is pinned on various things.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Unilever, for instance (which I think is WPP's third biggest client) might decide to ramp up spending again in the second half having cut it in the first.

BE11:22am

The idea here is that Unilever has new products to launch which'll take spending. Or, alternatively, it might look at the share price at a record high and not bother. We don't know really.

BE11:22am

You have a few decent contract wins of late. The Sanofi account, for example, which WPP and Havas won off Publicis last week.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

The upshot though is not the fact that WPP's guided lower (again). It's that it might not have guided low enough.

BE11:23am

Or to put it in broker-ese, here's Barclays.

BE11:23am

July, at -2.6% net sales, is disappointing especially as it comes on easy comp; July 2016 was up 1.9%, below FY17 at 3.1%. If the two-year run rate holds, then July indicates negative growth for the full year. This combined with the second downgrade in FY guidance does little to reassure us that the FY guidance will be maintained. WPP still expects a stronger H2 due to easier comparables.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

And Citi .....

BE11:23am

While there is no point gilding the lily, we nevertheless make a couple of key points. First, the nature of the pressure on revenue is relatively narrow, even if it is deeper than originally feared. Second, while the headline shock is painful, the impact on consensus earnings is likely to be comparatively limited. The question then becomes: how much of this is already discounted in the c 25% relative derating already experienced YTD? We think much is and therefore think that this will in time be a 'buying opportunity', as pulling off the plaster gives the company an opportunity to 'reset the narrative'. For today, though, we expect the news to be taken poorly despite our Buy rating.

BE11:24am

And in terms of forecasts, Morgan Stanley.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Overall, these results suggest -4-5% to consensus 2017 EPS and -4% to 2018 EPS. Consensus would likely finish with EPS of 120p and 127p for 2017 and 2018 respectively vs current consensus at 125p/132p.

BE11:25am

Valuation metrics? Have Jefferies.

BE11:25am

WPP is trading on a discount to the subsector at 11.9x 2018E P/E vs. peers on 13.7x and a premium on EV/EBITDA at 8.8x vs. peers on 8.1x. WPP offers a 8.7% FCFY and 4% dividend yield.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

In terms of the sector, such as it is .....

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 164.01, down 1.7 (-1.02%), High: 165.50, Low: 161.90, Volume: 9.15m
BE11:26am

As noted on the right, big selloff early on. But as noted on the left, the UK seems to be the only bit of WPP that's functioning right now so it's come back a bit since.

11:27 am
undefined
BE11:27am

Okay, what else do we have?

BE11:28am

Quick line on the Ladbrokes story, I guess, just to close that particular loop.

11:27 am
Ladbrokes Coral Group PLC (LCL:LSE): Last: 119.50, down 0.3 (-0.25%), High: 122.20, Low: 119.40, Volume: 3.76m
PM11:28am

Oh yeah

PM11:01am

Hello and welcome to Markets Live

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Not sure the Panel would be delighted with that kind of structure.

PM11:29am

That's a good point

BE11:30am

Anyway, word of the approach leaked after it was dead and we wrote the obituary yesterday. End of story, for now.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

(@ROTR: Meggitt's a Jefferies upgrade. Don't get excited.)

PM11:30am

Well, for now

PM11:30am

One shrewdie I talk to was buying more yesterday late in the day

11:30 am
PM11:31am

But yes, we have to wait for the review now

BE11:31am

What's worth pondering for a moment is why GVC seems in such a hurry to put a deal together. I mean, Ladbrokes is nearly impossible to value right now given the regulatory uncertainty.

BE11:31am

Why not just wait?

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Now, one possible explanation there is GVC's exposure to Turkey.

PM11:32am

How so?

BE11:32am

Well, you'll remember GVC went into Turkey via the Sportingbet acquisition, back when it was the default buyer of bookies in unregulated markets.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Over the years it's fairly successfully used the market's derisking of those unregulated markets to acquire more stable revenues

BE11:33am

The purchase of a traditional bookmaker in the UK would be another big step in that process.

BE11:33am

But in the background, you have Erdogan.

11:34 am
PM11:34am

And he's not the derisking opportunity presented elsewhere previously...

PM11:34am

He frightens me actually

BE11:34am

Yes. Erdogran not really friendly to the gambling industry. He's not really friendly to lots of things, admittedly, but gambling's one he's been legislating recently.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

I note this all as a backdrop to the idea that GVC will consolidate the UK regular gambling industry. A lot of folk in the regular gambling industry have spent a lot of time avoiding going into places like Turkey ......

PM11:36am

(wayneJ -- Sept would be good, for 'reasons')

BE11:36am

Anyway, have some sellside. Here's Citi.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

According to the Financial Times recent bid talks between
GVC and LCL have broken down. Nevertheless that GVC was prepared to make an offer of 140p given the triennial review uncertainty highlights the value that exists in the sector and the scope for substantial synergies. Based on the reported “triennial review” contingency payment of up to 50p we calculate the multiple implied by the approach at only c8x EBITDA merely in line with the LT average for retail bookmaking businesses. We can see why LCL management would not think this attractive as there appears to be little or no premium for control and much of the triennial risk would likely remain if the deal was equity funded. Nevertheless we think this also implies that the triennial review risk is now substantially priced in.

BE11:38am

(@urgeview: percentage of revenues pinned geographically when speaking about online gambling isn't as simple a calculation as you'd hope.)

BE11:38am

8x multiple implied. We previously estimated the downside risk to earnings for LCL for a bearish below £10 triennial review outcome at c£110m (see report). Based on the reported 50p contingency payment (worth over £900m) this implies a multiple of just over 8x EBITDA. Assuming this is the relevant multiple that GVC would also pay for the overall group we calculate that it would need to find c£50m of synergies to achieve this “target” multiple assuming the above bearish triennial outcome (and the full benefit from the already announced Ladbrokes Coral merger synergies).

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Substantial synergies likely. Estimating synergies is problematic but we note LCL head office costs are £25m and we would expect substantial savings from moving LCL’s online business to the proprietary GVC platform. We also reference €125m of synergies in the GVC/BWIN merger and £150m of synergies in the more recent Ladbrokes/Coral merger which might suggest £50m is conservative.

BE11:39am

William Hill is similarly attractive. We see a similar value case at William Hill. Both LCL & WMH are trading at c7x FY17 EBITDA, falling to c6x in FY18. Applying a similar 15-20% premium (current price 244p), adjusting for the c£70m risk to earnings from a below £10 triennial review outcome (see report) and the same £50m synergies would also imply a multiple of c8x FY17 adjusted EBITDA (for a business with a greater online weighting). Adding back the earnings at risk from the triennial at a similar multiple would imply a share price of over 340p.

BE11:39am

Risks are manifold. Risks around the triennial review remain substantial. It is a political process but we have yet to see compelling evidence of causality between B2 machines and problem gambling. Further we see the negative implications for tax revenues, High Street employment and the horse racing industry as substantial. Although speculation has increased that lost retail tax revenues could be replaced by higher online taxes this seems to muddle the issues and would penalize a different set of operators which do not have retail estates. Risks exist in Australia from a possible POCT implementation but we see only single digit risk to earnings.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

That's James Ainley.

undefined
PM11:40am

Carillion

11:40 am
PM11:40am

Blimey

BE11:40am

Record low yesterday, even more so today.

PM11:41am

It's like the market has remembered that profit warnings tend to come in threes or more

11:41 am
PM11:41am

Find what's been hammered and hammer it some more

PM11:41am

Brutal

PM11:42am

But then we've said from the get-go of the Carillion drama that it would take some time to play out

11:42 am
Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 42.51, down 5.53 (-11.51%), High: 48.60, Low: 42.23, Volume: 5.24m
BE11:42am

We have results due September 29.

BE11:43am

It needs to come up with some kind of sustainable funding structure before that.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

There's been no indication whatsoever that disposals will be a prop.

BE11:44am

Equity will be needed. Whether that's in exchange for debt is a valid, increasingly pressing question.

BE11:44am

Bear in mind this thing now has a market cap in the range of £200m or so.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

Against liabilities of £1.6bn or so.

PM11:46am

sheesh

BE11:46am

The chances of survival and the interests of equity holders don't seem terribly aligned.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

(@Blue Horseshoe: send me your address and I'll send you a mouse with a scroll wheel.)

undefined
BE11:47am

Meggitt mentioned several times .....

11:47 am
Meggitt PLC (MGGT:LSE): Last: 515.50, up 18 (+3.62%), High: 517.00, Low: 505.50, Volume: 906.73k
BE11:48am

Dull reason, I'm afraid. Jefferies pushing.

BE11:48am

Meggitt's rejuvenation has taken a lot more than a good night's sleep (high R&D and PPCs in recent years, and out to FY20). The process will not be complete for some years, but with an "unprecedented" number of parts and systems won on new aircraft/engine programmes, its efficacy should be apparent within 12 months. We raise our PT from 500p to 600p. Our recommendation moves from Hold to Buy.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

This is Sandy Morris, of course. The only aerospace analyst who writes in English.

BE11:49am

Unprecedented. This adjective is applied twice in the 2016 annual report, once to the product renewal by the major airframe and engine manufacturers and then to the number of parts and sub-systems won from that development cycle. This is what we believe has permitted Meggitt to address the maturity of its installed base in Aircraft Braking Systems and Control Systems.

BE11:49am

Finally happening. The above success came at a high cost in terms of R&D and Programme Participation Costs (PPCs - essentially losses on OE brakes). The former has now peaked, but PPCs will likely rise through FY20, in our view. However, new products are now entering production facilities "faster than ever". Instead of just costs (and cash outflows), we believe revenue will start to gain momentum from 2H17. Passage of the US FY18 Defense Budget could provide an incremental fillip to Military sales, in our view.

11:49 am
PM11:50am

'efficacy' spread to aircraft parts industry i see

BE11:50am

Rejuvenation. The years of investment ahead of production have required endurance - we have bided our time until convinced tangible rewards should be evident within our 12-month horizon.

BE11:50am

It's a useful word, to be fair.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Much as we liked to snipe at it under previous management.

BE11:51am

What other word means efficacy? I welcome it into the corporate bumf lexicon.

undefined
11:51 am
PM11:51am

(ALM -- it's not just Woodford factor. Remember Invesco are reducing as well. Can't see when that thing stablises, sadly. It needs to monetise some of its IP.)

PM11:52am

I was just happy to see the back of efficacy when Pearson sold us

PM11:52am

efficacy was Fallon's favourite word

11:53 am
undefined
PM11:53am

Have we run out of things to say?

PM11:54am

We could discuss having a meet up next month -- while since we did one of those

11:54 am
BE11:54am

We've not quite run out yet! I could say that efficacy has the Latin root of efficere, to accomplish. But that'd be one small step from talking about the news desk cheeseboard.

PM11:54am

And @ epicurean
@alewis2005 -- don't be shy. They are friendly affairs

PM11:55am

How do you know all this shit Bryce?

11:54 am
BE11:55am

In this case, Google.

PM11:55am

You're scaring @ epicurean
@alewis2005

BE11:55am

It's fine, I probably won't be there. I think I'm busy that night.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

Anyway, want some more sellside to pass the time?

BE11:56am

Cannacord calling the top on Persimmon

BE11:56am

We downgrade Persimmon to a HOLD rating solely on valuation grounds, after its very strong share price run. Operationally the group is delivering exceptionally well, supported by good trading momentum. We see more upside in completions and profits over the next few years and its strong balance sheet positions it very well to navigate potentially more challenging trading conditions. We expect it to pay 135p in dividends per annum to 2021 and would not be surprised if a revised commitment exceeded this in February, assuming trading holds up over the next six months. Clearly management is doing an exceptional job at delivering on its strategy clearly set out a few years back, but after such a strong run, we believe that the risk:reward equation does not look as favourable as it has over the last twelve months. We have increased our profit estimates modestly and our price target moves up to 2,650p.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

The shares have been one of the strongest performers in the sector YTD. The performance of the group has justified such a strong share price performance and valuation premium to the sector. We believe that the current valuation looks relatively full on a 2017E P/NAV multiple of c.2.8 times with a dividend yield of c.5.2%. Adjusting our 2018E NAV estimate to assume a zero cash balance would imply a NAV per share of c.600p with c.440p of cash per share. Deducting 440p from the current share price would imply a cash adjusted NAV multiple of c.3.5 times, which looks relatively full based on a reasonable implied return on equity and cost of equity. Strong delivery supports current valuation but risk:reward looks less attractive at the current levels. We increase our target price to 2650p (from 2,570p) based on a weighted average of two valuation methodologies: P/NAV multiple and dividend yield.

Persimmon PLC (PSN:LSE): Last: 2,577, down 24 (-0.92%), High: 2,589, Low: 2,547, Volume: 524.84k
BE11:58am

And of course there's a whole slew of Provident Financial downgrades from buy, which I'll not draw attention to out of courtesy to those already wondering about their futures under MifidII.

11:58 am
PM11:59am

(warneJ -- 21 lunch sounds good to me. Could do 22 lunch, but i have a dinner that night)

BE11:59am

Do read Woodford on Provident from last night, though: https://woodfordfu...ovident-financial/

BE12:00pm

Despite today’s profit warning, the company is still expected to post a profit at the group level of at least £80m this year. Looking into next year, there is still a lot of uncertainty around forecasts but if we assume some stabilisation in the consumer credit division with a smaller customer base, along with other conservatively-struck assumptions about the rest of the business, the group should deliver pre-tax profit in excess of £300m in 2019. This equates to approximately 160p in earnings per share in 2019, which at the time of writing represents a price / earnings ratio of around 3x. If we assume the resumption of dividends with a 50% pay-out ratio, an 80p dividend would equate to around 15% dividend yield.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Hmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm ,,,,,,,,,,,,

Provident Financial PLC (PFG:LSE): Last: 602.20, up 12.7 (+2.15%), High: 618.50, Low: 540.00, Volume: 4.70m
PM12:01pm

What else is he going to say!

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

Thing with Woodford is that he didn't make enough friends on the way up.

PM12:01pm

Openly slagged off the rest of the asset management industry

PM12:02pm

And now he's hit real turbulence and everyone goes

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Well ..... It's a long way back for him, and for it to be a long way back you have to convince the consensus that a PE / yield approach is in any way valid for a stock that's just erased £200m of earnings and clawed back its interim div because of one botched restructuring of its headcount.

PM12:02pm

shrug

BE12:02pm

Maybe he's right! But it's going to take a long, long time to demonstrate it.

12:02 pm
PM12:03pm

I'm shrugging to end my sentence, not at what you are writing Bryce

BE12:03pm

Anyway, have another buyer. SocGen.

BE12:04pm

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

BE12:05pm

(Cut and pasted because SocGen's PDF formatting is irritating.)

PM12:05pm

Cheers for that

12:05 pm
undefined
PM12:06pm

Look at the time Bryce

PM12:06pm

I've got loads of stuff to do

12:05 pm
PM12:06pm

Other stuff

PM12:06pm

But thanks for all that above!

PM12:07pm

No statement out of Rhythm One Cry smile

12:07 pm
PM12:07pm

See, we're rubbish. Or at least I am

PM12:07pm

Thanks for joining us on the right

PM12:07pm

Back tomorrow

12:07 pm
PM12:07pm

Bye

BE11:29am

Confirmation yesterday that GVC did put in an approach a week or so ago, with an interesting structure involving a 50p kicker if the Triennial puggie review comes out okay.
